conclusion: As the lamp is raised straight upward (same horizontal position), the rays that reach the ground become more vertical.
The more vertical the rays, the shorter the distance the rays have to travel horizontally before they hit the ground.

premise: The rays have a shorter horizontal travel distance.
conclusion: Every shadow slides inward, i.e., its centre drifts toward the point of contact of the object with the ground.

premise: The rays have a shorter horizontal travel distance.
conclusion: Every shadow becomes smaller (its outline contracts) because the “projection cone” narrows.
A is an apple with a nearly spherical shape.
Its circular shadow will move a little closer to the point where the apple touches the table.
The diameter of the dark ring will decrease slightly; the shadow keeps its round shape.
B is a small flag or cloth, thin and rectangular, standing upright.
The rectangular patch will slide toward the pole/foot of the flag.
Because the flag is thin but tall, its shadow height shrinks noticeably; the outline stays wavy-rectangular but is overall smaller.
C is a glass cup, transparent, with a thin rim.

premise: C is transparent with a thin rim.
conclusion: The faint ring‐like shadow produced by refraction/reflection moves inward as with the other objects.

premise: C is transparent with a thin rim.
conclusion: The dark parts (rim and stem) contract; the already pale floor-brightening inside the ring becomes even smaller and closer to the glass base.
The elongated irregular shadow shifts toward the bone tip resting on the slab.
Both the “meaty” oval part and the thin bone projection shorten; the whole silhouette tightens around the contact area.

premise: When the light source is raised vertically, every shadow (A, B, C, D) slides inward toward the foot of its object and becomes proportionally smaller; their general shapes are preserved but each outline is a compacted version of what is seen with the lower light.
conclusion: A, B, C and D move to the front left and become shorter.
